author: rmbolger
body:
I have an API that expects to receive a `Content-Type` header in a particular GET request. When it does not get that header, it returns an HTTP 415 'Unsupported Media Type' response. I realize this API is probably non-conforming to the HTTP spec. Under normal circumstances, it is probably correct that PowerShell strips the `Content-Type` header from GET requests. However, the [docs for `SkipHeaderValidation`](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/powershell/module/microsoft.powershell.utility/invoke-webrequest) make it seem like that would be a workaround.

> This switch should be used for sites that require header values that do not conform to standards. Specifying this switch disables validation to allow the value to be passed unchecked. When specified, all headers are added without validation.

> This will disable validation for values passed to the -ContentType, -Headers and -UserAgent parameters.

It should be noted that the API call works and the Content-Type header is passed normally in Windows PowerShell 5.1 despite the lack of the SkipHeaderValidation parameter.

# Steps to reproduce

```powershell
(Invoke-WebRequest https://httpbin.org/get -ContentType 'application/force-download' -SkipHeaderValidation).Content

# or

(Invoke-WebRequest https://httpbin.org/get -Headers @{'Content-Type'='application/force-download'} -SkipHeaderValidation).Content
```

# Expected behavior

```none
{
  "args": {},
  "headers": {
    "Content-Type": "application/force-download",
    "Host": "httpbin.org",
    "User-Agent": "Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 10.0; Microsoft Windows 10.0.17134; en-US) PowerShell/6.2.0"
  },
  "origin": "xxx.xxx.xxx.xxx, xxx.xxx.xxx.xxx",
  "url": "https://httpbin.org/get"
}
```

# Actual behavior

```none
{
  "args": {},
  "headers": {
    "Host": "httpbin.org",
    "User-Agent": "Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 10.0; Microsoft Windows 10.0.17134; en-US) PowerShell/6.2.0"
  },
  "origin": "xxx.xxx.xxx.xxx, xxx.xxx.xxx.xxx",
  "url": "https://httpbin.org/get"
}
```

# Environment data

<!-- provide the output of $PSVersionTable -->

```none

----                           -----

PSEdition                      Core
GitCommitId                    6.2.0

WSManStackVersion              3.0
```

@markekraus

comments.author: vexx32
comments.body:
/cc @markekraus 

From what I remember of some recent issues, there's an issue (by design? I'm not sure) where the cmdlet ignores `Content-Type` headers and the parameter when `-Body` is not set on the request.

comments.author: markekraus
comments.body: For clarity, its the same underlying issue that causes both of these behaviors.

comments.author: rmbolger
comments.body: Setting an empty body does indeed workaround the problem. Ironically, the empty body causes a ProtocolViolationException on Windows PowerShell 5.1. But I can work around that too.

title: Web Cmdlets strip ContentType header on GET requests even with -SkipHeaderValidation
